events.originalText: Hong Kong–based writer and publisher Gui Minhai, known for writing about Chinese Communist Party politicians, was sentenced to ten years' imprisonment for intelligence violations.
events.subtitle: Gui Minhai
events.headline: Gui Minhai sentenced to ten years for intelligence violations

events.originalText: At their headquarters in Pilkhana, members of the Bangladesh Rifles began a mutiny that resulted in 82 deaths.
events.subtitle: Pilkhana, Bangladesh
events.headline: Bangladesh Rifles mutiny results in 82 deaths

events.originalText: Israeli physician Baruch Goldstein opened fire on Muslim Arabs praying at the mosque in Hebron's Cave of the Patriarchs, killing 29 people and wounding 125 others.
events.subtitle: Baruch Goldstein
events.headline: Baruch Goldstein kills 29 in Hebron mosque shooting

events.originalText: Philippine dictator Ferdinand Marcos and his wife Imelda were ousted from power by the non-violent People Power Revolution, with Corazon Aquino succeeding as president.
events.subtitle: Ferdinand Marcos
events.headline: Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos ousted in People Power Revolution

events.originalText: The first prime minister of independent Suriname, Henck Arron (pictured), was deposed in a military coup led by Dési Bouterse.
events.subtitle: Henck Arron
events.headline: Suriname's first PM Henck Arron deposed in military coup

events.originalText: In a speech to the 20th Congress of the Communist Party, Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev denounced the personality cult and dictatorship of his predecessor Joseph Stalin.
events.subtitle: On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences
events.headline: Khrushchev denounces Stalin at Communist Party Congress

events.originalText: After being postponed due to World War II, the inaugural Pan American Games opened in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
events.subtitle: 1951 Pan American Games
events.headline: Inaugural Pan American Games open in Buenos Aires

events.originalText: Fearful of civil war and Soviet intervention in recent unrest, President Edvard Beneš (pictured) ceded control of the government to the Communist Party of Czechoslovakia.
events.subtitle: Edvard Beneš
events.headline: President Beneš cedes control to Communist Party in Czechoslovakia

events.originalText: USS Ranger, the United States Navy's first purpose-built aircraft carrier, was launched.
events.subtitle: USS Ranger (CV-4)
events.headline: USS Ranger launched as first purpose-built aircraft carrier

events.originalText: Mississippi senator Hiram Rhodes Revels became the first African American to be seated in the U.S. Congress.
events.subtitle: United States Senate
events.headline: Hiram Rhodes Revels first African American seated in U.S. Congress

events.originalText: Miners in Calaveras County, California, discovered a human skull that was taken to show that humans had existed during the Pliocene, a thesis that was later disproved.
events.subtitle: Calaveras County, California
events.headline: Human skull discovery in Calaveras County disproves Pliocene thesis

events.originalText: Royal Navy captain Lord George Paulet began a five-month occupation of the Hawaiian Islands.
events.subtitle: Royal Navy
events.headline: Lord George Paulet occupies Hawaiian Islands

events.originalText: George Frideric Handel's opera Nero premiered in Hamburg.
events.subtitle: George Frideric Handel
events.headline: Handel's opera Nero premieres in Hamburg

events.originalText: Khosrow II, the last great king of the Sasanian Empire, was overthrown by his son Kavad II.
events.subtitle: Khosrow II
events.headline: Khosrow II overthrown by son Kavad II in Sasanian Empire

events.originalText: Roman emperor Hadrian adopted Antoninus Pius as his son and successor following the death of Hadrian's first adopted son Lucius Aelius.
events.subtitle: AD 138
events.headline: Hadrian adopts Antoninus Pius as successor
